abstracts.cdata!:
The Kenya Public Sector Management
            Technical Assistance Project had an unsatisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, and unsatisfactory Bank and Borrower performances.
            The report cites four four lessons: (a) When re-establishing
            a relationship with a country, keep reforms simple: Since
            policy dialogue with the Government was low in the past,
            much cannot be expected to be achieved under a project that
            requires major policy reforms. (b) Build adequate support
            and coalition among all stakeholders, including
            parliamentarians, when preparing reforms and drafting bills.
            The project life of three years was too short for any
            meaningful policy reforms to be carried out successfully.
            (c) Develop an effective communications strategy to
            communicate the benefits of the reform during preparation
            and implementation: The Government and the Bank designed the
            project without much involving civil society groups, the
            private sector, and parliament. The new party in government
            has to appreciate the issues and the rationale for reforms.
            (d) Align appropriate institutional arrangements with the
            champions of the project: During preparation, identify the
            political champions responsible for the various reform
            processes which have wide political ramifications.
            Managerial responsibility for the project should be assigned
            to someone who clearly has the authority, means, and stature
            to carry out the reforms. Furthermore, the report cites
            recommendations from a governance review completed by
            forensic auditors, which found shortcomings but not fraud.
            The recommendations include making fraud-risk management an
            integral part of all future projects; having the Project
            Steering Committee take an active leadership role in project
            governance; and requiring strong leadership from those
            entities having the primary responsibility to spearheadi
            public sector reforms.
